justification: The authors note that "there are several scales that measure physical contagion sensitivity, such as the Perceived Vulnerability to Disease scale (Duncan et al., 2009)."

measured_by: Vancouver Obsessional Compulsive Inventory – Contamination subscale
justification: They list "the Vancouver Obsessional Compulsive Inventory, Contamination subscale (Thordarson et al., 2004)" as another tool that "measure[s] physical contagion sensitivity."
The text states that "the Disgust Scale… include items which measure physical contagion beliefs," linking this instrument to the construct of physical contagion sensitivity.
The paper introduces "a 12-item scale" and explains that "the present studies develop and validate… measures of spiritual contagion sensitivity (SCS)."

measured_by: Spiritual Contagion Sensitivity scale – Short Form (3-item)
justification: Under "Development of a Short Form of the Scale," the authors describe creating "a short-form (3-item) version of the scale" to assess spiritual contagion sensitivity.

measured_by: Negative subscale of the Spiritual Contagion Sensitivity scale
justification: Study 1 confirms a three-factor structure, noting four items that "capture negative spiritual contagion" and load on a distinct factor, establishing a dedicated negative subscale.

measured_by: Positive subscale of the Spiritual Contagion Sensitivity scale
justification: The scale includes "four statements about positive spiritual contagion," and factor analysis shows these items load together as the positive subscale measuring sensitivity to positive spiritual contagion.

measured_by: Neutral subscale of the Spiritual Contagion Sensitivity scale
justification: The authors specify "four statements about neutral spiritual contagion" that form a separate factor, indicating a neutral subscale intended to measure neutral spiritual contagion sensitivity.
